resources.text: Your task is to create a generic class that behaves like java.util.stream.Stream.
resources.boxed: The real Stream interface and its implementation is very complicated. In this task, you only need to create a class works similarly to the original, and you won't even have to implement all stream operations.
resources.text: I suggest you use a collection to store the elements of your "stream". In my solution, I'll use a list.
Have a static method of your class that can convert any Collection into your stream. Hide the constructor.
resources.boxed: For converting your stream back into collections, have two methods, collectToList and collectToSet. You don't have to bother writing classes similar to Collectors.
resources.text: Implement at least the following stream operations for your class:
resources.list:
• Filtering.
  • Mapping to a different stream.
  • Matching: the anyMatch and allMatch methods.
  • Counting.
  • Iterating: the forEach method.
  • Getting the first element: the findFirst method.
resources.advanced: Feel free to implement more stream operations. You can browse the original Stream's methods for inspiration here.
resources.text: It's important that all your stream operations take functional interfaces as parameters, just like the real ones. This will allow you to pass in lambda expressions. Also make sure that you can "chain" the operations. You can achieve that with the return values.
resources.boxed: You can use the original Stream inside your implementation, but I suggest you do not, as it might lead to some confusion (method names will be the same as your methods).

solution.text: I created the MyStream class, which implements all the necessary operations:
solution.code:
public class MyStream<T> {

    //stores the elements of the stream
    private final List<T> elements;
    
    //static method to create streams
    public static <T> MyStream<T> of(Collection<T> collection) {
         return new MyStream<>(collection);
    }
    
    //private constructor
    private MyStream(Collection<T> collection) {
         elements = new LinkedList<T>(collection);
    }
    
    //collecting to a list
    public List<T> collectToList() {
         return new LinkedList<T>(elements);
    }
    
    //collecting to set
    public Set<T> collectToSet() {
         return new HashSet<T>(elements);
    }
    
    //filtering
    public MyStream<T> filter(Predicate<T> predicate) {
         /*
          * Make a copy, since you can get ConcurrentModificationException
          * if you remove elements while iterating.
          */
         List<T> copy = new LinkedList<>(elements);
         //iterate over the copy and remove from original
         for(T element: copy) {
              if(!predicate.test(element)) elements.remove(element);
         }
         return this;
    }
    
    //mapping to another stream
    public <S> MyStream<S> map(Function<T,S> mapper) {
         List<S> newElements = new LinkedList<>();
         //transform all elements
         for(T element: elements) {
              newElements.add(mapper.apply(element));
         }
         return new MyStream<>(newElements);
    }
    
    //anyMatch function
    public boolean anyMatch(Predicate<T> predicate) {
         for(T element: elements) {
              if(predicate.test(element)) return true;
         }
         return false;
    }
    
    //allMatch function
    public boolean allMatch(Predicate<T> predicate) {
         for(T element: elements) {
              if(!predicate.test(element)) return false;
         }
         return true;
    }
    
    //counting elements
    public int count() {
         return elements.size();
    }
    
    //iterating
    public void forEach(Consumer<T> consumer) {
         for(T element: elements) {
              consumer.accept(element);
         }
    }
    
    //getting the first element
    public Optional<T> findFirst() {
         if(elements.size() > 0) {
              return Optional.of(elements.get(0));
         } else {
              return Optional.empty();
         }
    }
}
